entry.title: Custom Fields in Monitor Purchase Requisition Report
entry.content:
Dear Team,

 

In the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items application, the client requires a few additional columns to be displayed, including:

 

  • PR Approver Name
  • PR Approval Date
  • PR Approval Time
  • Purchase Order
  • Purchase Order Item
  • PO Approver Name
  • PO Approval Date
  • PO Approval Time (Days)

 



 

We have checked for available BADIs related to this report but could not find any suitable options to add these custom fields.

 

 

 

Kindly suggest an appropriate BADI to add the custom fields to the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items application or advise how to develop a new custom report by copying the existing Monitor Purchase Requisition Items report to add mentioned custom fields.

 

 

 

Please provide a solution at the earliest

Regards,

entry.title: Re: Custom Fields in Monitor Purchase Requisition Report
entry.content:
Dear Team,

Thank you for your query.

We reviewed the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items application and confirmed that, in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the system does not provide any BADI or extensibility option to add additional fields such as PR/PO approver details, approval timestamps, or PO references directly into this standard app.

This application is built on a standard analytical data model that cannot be modified through enhancements or UI extensions.

Recommended and Supported Approach

Kindly explore the CDS views : SAP Business Accelerator Hub 

Summary

Since the standard app cannot be enhanced, the custom analytical report approach is the recommended method to deliver all required additional fields in a compliant and upgrade-safe way.

The following cases are classified as consulting requests and should not be raised via a Support incident. This includes inquiries concerning:

    1. Advice or assistance relating to configuration, business process analysis, or implementation specific to the customer‚Äôs unique environment or already documented in Product Guides.
    2. ‚ÄòHow-To‚Äô questions seeking assistance with documented features.
    3. Assistance with customization of the core product, core functionality and/or problems or errors caused by customization that has been implemented or completed by customers or partners.

Best Regards, 
Aishwarya

entry.title: SAP-RPT-1: A Revolutionary Tabular ML Model and OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance
entry.content:
Note: This blog discusses SAP-RPT-1 model, the enterprise version of the ConTextTab / SAP-RPT-1-OSS model architecture. The underlying technology is detailed in the ConTextTab research paper published by SAP, with an open-source implementation available as ConTextTab on Hugging Face and GitHub.

The Challenge: Traditional Tabular ML's Security Dilemma

In the world of enterprise machine learning, tabular data represents the backbone of business intelligence from customer analytics to financial forecasting. However, traditional tabular ML approaches have long faced a fundamental security challenge: the need for extensive fine-tuning on customer data.

When organisations deploy conventional ML models, they must:
- Fine-tune models using sensitive customer data, permanently modifying model weights
- Store customer information within model parameters, creating privacy risks
- Manage complex security frameworks to protect against data poisoning, model inversion, and membership inference attacks
- Navigate compliance requirements while maintaining model performance

This creates a paradox: the more effective the model becomes through fine-tuning, the greater the security risks it introduces.

Enter SAP-RPT-1: Redefining Tabular Machine Learning

The Breakthrough: In-Context Learning for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 represents a paradigm shift in tabular machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. Built on the principle of In-Context Learning (ICL), SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance without ever modifying its core model weights.

How SAP-RPT-1 Works: A Security-First Architecture

Unlike traditional models that require fine-tuning, SAP-RPT-1 operates through a fundamentally different mechanism:

  1. Customer provides data (tables) examples as context
  2. Model processes examples in real-time without storing or learning from them
  3. Predictions are made based on patterns identified in the provided context
  4. Customer data is immediately discarded after prediction completion

This approach delivers two critical advantages:
- Superior performance through semantic understanding of tabular relationships
- Inherent security advantages through its ephemeral processing approach, addressing several traditional ML vulnerability categories.

The Technical Innovation: Seven Pillars of Security-by-Design

SAP-RPT-1 revolutionary approach is built on seven fundamental characteristics that naturally eliminate most machine learning security risks:

1. Specialized Architecture for Tabular Data

SAP-RPT-1 is fundamentally a classification and regression model designed specifically for structured data, not a Large Language Model. This focus makes it subject to the OWASP ML Top 10 security framework rather than LLM-specific vulnerabilities, providing a clearer security assessment pathway.

2. In-Context Learning vs. Traditional Fine-Tuning

The core innovation lies in SAP-RPT-1 learning approach:
- Traditional Fine-tuning: Permanently modifies model weights using customer data, creating persistent security risks
- SAP-RPT-1 ICL: Uses customer data as contextual examples within the input, without modifying any model parameters
- Security Advantage: Eliminates risks associated with model weight manipulation and data persistence

3. Enterprise API-First Security Model

- Fully managed API service: SAP handles all infrastructure, security, and model management while customers interact exclusively through secure, authenticated API endpoints
-  Enterprise-grade security: Leverages SAP's proven security frameworks and compliance standards to safeguard SAP-RPT-1, while the base architecture remains transparently published through the open-source SAP-RPT-1-OSS version
- Controlled environment: All predictions occur within SAP's secure infrastructure

4. Customer Data Dependency as a Security Feature

SAP-RPT-1 ICL architecture creates an inherent security advantage:
- No standalone inference: Model requires customer-provided historical examples for every prediction
- Customer data control: Prediction quality directly depends on customer-provided context
- Reduced poisoning risk: Traditional attacks like model poisoning and data poisoning become significantly limited
- Contextual relevance: Model can only make predictions within the scope of provided examples

 5. Ephemeral Processing Architecture

Every SAP-RPT-1 inference follows a secure, temporary processing model:
- Memory-only processing: Customer data exists solely during the inference request
- No weight updates: Model parameters remain completely unchanged throughout operation
- Zero persistence: No traces of customer information remain in the model

6. Enterprise-Grade SAP Management

As a SAP-provided service, SAP-RPT-1 benefits from comprehensive enterprise security controls:
- Supply chain security: Direct SAP control over model development, training, and distribution
- Model integrity: Protection against unauthorised modifications and tampering
- Data governance & compliance:   SAP ensures that all data used to train its Foundation Model follows strict regulations to protect privacy and meet legal standards. SAP has robust security policies to manage data safely when developing its applications.
- Quality assurance: Professional model validation and continuous security testing

7. Secure Semantic Processing Pipeline

SAP-RPT-1 employs a mathematically based data processing approach that eliminates code execution risks:

All inputs (strings, numbers, dates, etc.) are transformed into embeddings (vector representations of the data), and these embeddings undergo pure mathematical transformations within the model with no code execution occurring during data processing, only mathematical operations on numerical vectors: Inputs (e.g., strings, numbers, dates) ‚Üí Vector Embeddings ‚Üí Mathematical Operations ‚Üí Prediction Result.

Security guarantees:
- No code execution pathways in data processing
- Pure mathematical tensor operations throughout the pipeline
- Semantic understanding without security vulnerabilities
- Input sanitization through numerical conversion

SAP-RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance

With SAP-RPT-1 architecture established, we can now examine how these design principles address the industry-standard OWASP ML Top 10 security framework. This assessment demonstrates that SAP-RPT-1 innovative approach doesn't just match traditional security measures, it fundamentally eliminates most attack vectors entirely.

SAP RPT-1 & OWASP ML Top 10 Compliance Overview

OWASP ML Top 10Risk Applicability to SAP RPT-1Risk Assessment Technical RationaleSecurity Status
ML01: Input Manipulation AttackApplicableMinimal exposure due to customer-controlled data model

Customers provide their own contextual examples, significantly reducing adversarial input scenarios. Risk limited to compromised customer environments.

Customer Managed
ML02: Data Poisoning AttackNot ApplicableArchitecture prevents traditional data poisoning

In-Context Learning does not modify model weights. Customer data serves only as contextual input during inference, with no persistent model updates.

Inherently Protected
ML03: Model Inversion AttackNot ApplicableNo sensitive training data to extractCustomer data is ephemeral and not embedded in model weights. No gradient information exposed through API.Inherently Protected
ML04: Membership Inference AttackNot ApplicableSAP regulated training data eliminates attack vectorNo customer data persists in model, eliminating membership inference opportunities.Inherently Protected
ML05: Model TheftNot ApplicableSAP-managed infrastructure prevents model parameter accessSAP-RPT-1 is provided and managed within SAP's secure infrastructure. Customers access only the API endpoint, never the model parameters . Further since customer provided context is not saved in model due to ICL, model theft has no impact on customersInherently Protected
ML06: AI Supply Chain AttacksNot ApplicableSAP as trusted model provider eliminates supply chain riskSAP is the official model provider with direct control over development, training, and distribution. No third-party supply chain vulnerabilities.Inherently Protected
ML07: Transfer Learning AttackNot ApplicableNo transfer learning in deployment architectureIn-Context Learning eliminates transfer learning attack vectors entirely..Inherently Protected
ML08: Model Skewing ApplicableCustomer data quality responsibilityPotential for unintentional bias in customer-provided data. Model leverages  patterns present in contextual examples, requiring customer awareness and data curation.Customer Managed
ML09: Output Integrity AttackApplicableStandard API security controls applyRisk can be mitigated through conventional authentication and authorization mechanisms.Customer Managed
ML10: Model PoisoningNot ApplicableImmutable model architecturePre-trained model weights remain completely unchanged during operation. Customer data cannot modify base model behaviour or parameters.Inherently Protected

The Results: A New Standard for Secure ML

SAP-RPT-1 Security Achievement

The OWASP ML Top 10 compliance reveals SAP-RPT-1 remarkable security profile:

Inherent Protection Against 7 out of 10 Major Threats
SAP-RPT-1 In-Context Learning architecture provides built-in protection against most ML security risks. Unlike traditional systems that require extensive security hardening, SAP-RPT-1 design reduces the likelihood of most attack vectors by default.

Standard Controls for Remaining Risks
The three-remaining low-risk areas (Input Manipulation, Model Skewing, and Output Integrity) are addressed through conventional security measures that organisations typically already have in place:
- Input validation and API security controls
- Customer data governance
- Standard authentication and authorization mechanisms

Customer Empowerment Through Data Control
Rather than creating security burdens, SAP-RPT-1 empowers customers by giving them direct control over model behaviour through their own data, while eliminating the risks associated with traditional model training.

References:
- OWASP ML Security Top 10
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Paper
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Model
- SAP-RPT-1-OSS / ConTextTab Github
- SAP-RPT-1 Model FAQ
- Know more on SAP-RPT-1 Model

entry.title: Re: Output tax field in the customer master.
entry.content:
For information, tax determination is not controlled directly by fields in the customer master. Instead, it is driven by Tax Departure Country/Region (Dep. Country/Region) ‚Üí taken from the supplying plant or company code, Customer‚Äôs destination country/region ‚Üí taken from the customer master (address data) and Tax condition records ‚Üí maintained in Manage Tax Records app. The ‚ÄúOutput Tax‚Äù field you see in the customer master is essentially a tax classification indicator, not a place to add new countries.

In order to add another Country/Region, in your case, it is US, Go to Manage Your Solution ‚Üí Configure Tax on Sales and Purchases. Add the US as a departure country/region for tax determination. In the Business Partner (Customer Master), under Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Billing ‚Üí Output Tax, you can assign tax classifications per country/region. If you want to see ‚ÄúUS‚Äù appear here, you must first configure the tax departure country/region in SSCUI. Use the Manage Tax Records app to define tax codes for the US. Link them to the departure country/region and customer tax classification.

entry.title: Re: RAP event - Additional save > Raise Event > INSERT ge...
entry.content:
Thanks for the quick reply! I do understand German, so let's give the webinar a go üôÇ

Setting the phase to SAVE manually right before the method that performs the INSERT, does fix that specific command. Unfortunately, a little further down the line (still in the standard SAP method) a WAIT command is issued, which is apparently not allowed in the SAVE phase. *sigh* 

A "CALL <save>" call is active with "CL_PRINT_QUEUE_UTILS". The current statement "WAIT" is therefore forbidden.

But good to know we can (and probably should) set the phase manually, thanks for that insight!

Picking List

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/87f9b54f9c4f4e75aff0061860a6589a/82cf810979654983b2c505f1f3154987.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

 

Packing List

entry.title: Re: fixed quantity indicator in standard costing estimate
entry.content:
Yes why this happens is because, Costing explosion in CK11N follows the quantity structure of BOMs and routings. For fixed‚Äëquantity components, costing only respects the flag if the component is directly under the costed material‚Äôs BOM. When the fixed‚Äëquantity component is under a lower‚Äëlevel semi‚Äëfinished BOM, the system multiplies it by the semi‚Äëfinished quantity, because the costing run treats the semi‚Äëfinished product as a proportional input.

Options to avoid this issue are

Place the raw material directly in the finished product BOM (instead of under the semi‚Äëfinished). This way, CK11N will correctly treat it as fixed and not scale it with the semi‚Äëfinished quantity.

Run CK11N with a costing lot size = 1 for the semi‚Äëfinished product. This ensures the fixed quantity is applied once, not multiplied by the semi‚Äëfinished lot size. You can set costing lot sizes in the material master (Costing view).

Model the semi‚Äëfinished product as a phantom assembly (special BOM usage). Phantom assemblies explode into the parent BOM during costing, so the fixed‚Äëquantity component is treated as if it belongs to the finished product BOM.

entry.title: Re: SAP BAS - Simulate REST API with Oauth
entry.content:
@RomnickJohn 

You need to add the following configuration to package.json:

  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "TES_CWT_H_DEST": {
        "kind": "rest",
        "credentials": {
          "destination": "TES_CWT_H_DEST"
        }
      }
    }

Also, execute the following command to bind the destination service:

cds bind 2 <destinationServiceInstance>

Then, execute the service in hybrid mode:

cds watch --profile hybrid

entry.title: Re: What does "Price Category HF" mean?
entry.content: The item ‚ÄúPrice Category HF‚Äù in the BCPricingChanges sheet refers to Hotfix (HF) price category changes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. It is not a new functional field in the customer master or pricing itself, but rather an internal classification used by SAP to indicate that a Business Catalog (BC) or pricing‚Äërelated change is delivered as part of a Hotfix Collection (HF). In other words, ‚ÄúPrice Category HF‚Äù is a marker that the pricing change is tied to a hotfix release cycle, not a notice of future price category changes for customers. Have a look at this blog Understanding the Price Category information by @Tayane

entry.title: Re: How to dynamically split comma-separated values into...
entry.content:
I just tired this in SQL console in SAP HANA , you can try it in SQL View data sphere 

@archanareddy_2511 wrote:

I am working in SAP Datasphere (Data Builder ‚Äì Graphical View) and I have a column that contains comma-separated values inside a single row. Example:

ID

Observee(s)

19195

0039270, 0040932, 00051689

43400

00055233

121461

NULL

My requirement is to dynamically split these comma-separated values into individual rows, like this:

ID

Observee

19195

0039270

19195

0040932

19195

00051689

43400

00055233

I need a solution that is 

Dynamic (not limited to a fixed number of values like 5 or 10)

 Works in SAP Datasphere (Graphical View OR HANA SQL

Works even when:

  • number of comma-separated values varies per row
  • values sometimes contain spaces
  • column type is NVARCHAR
  • JSON_TABLE or STRING_TO_TABLE are not supported
  • Recursion is not enabled in Datasphere SQL View 
  • So far, I tried:
  • JSON_TABLE() ‚Üí not supported
  • STRING_TO_TABLE() ‚Üí not supported
  • Recursive CTE ‚Üí not allowed inside Data Builder SQL View
  • Regular expression functions ‚Üí no REGEXP_SUBSTR in Graphical View
  • Calculated Columns ‚Üí no built-in SPLIT or explode function

Is there any recommended Datasphere pattern for splitting CSV string fields into multiple records?

Is this possible in:

  • Graphical View (Projection, Aggregation, Calculated Column, etc.)
    or
  • SQL View using functions supported by SAP HANA Cloud?

If someone can provide either:

A working SQL example

or

A correct modeling approach in Datasphere

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

WITH source_data AS (
SELECT 19195 AS id, '0039270,0040932,00051689' AS observees FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 43400, '00055233' FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 121461, NULL FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 55555, '12345,67890' FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL
SELECT 88888, '0001,0002,0003,0004' FROM DUMMY
),
numbers AS (
SELECT 1 AS n FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 2 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 3 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 4 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 5 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 6 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 7 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 8 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 9 FROM DUMMY
UNION ALL SELECT 10 FROM DUMMY
)
SELECT
s.id,
TRIM(
CASE
WHEN INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n) = 0 THEN
SUBSTRING(s.observees,
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END,
1000)
ELSE
SUBSTRING(s.observees,
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END,
INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n) -
CASE WHEN n.n = 1 THEN 1 ELSE INSTR(s.observees, ',', 1, n.n - 1) + 1 END
)
END
) AS observee
FROM source_data s
JOIN numbers n
ON n.n <= LENGTH(s.observees) - LENGTH(REPLACE(s.observees, ',', '')) + 1
WHERE s.observees IS NOT NULL
ORDER BY s.id, observee;

  • Calculated Columns ‚Üí no built-in SPLIT or explode function

Is there any recommended Datasphere pattern for splitting CSV string fields into multiple records?

Is this possible in:

  • Graphical View (Projection, Aggregation, Calculated Column, etc.)
    or
  • SQL View using functions supported by SAP HANA Cloud?

If someone can provide either:

A working SQL example

or

A correct modeling approach in Datasphere

entry.title: Why do parked supplier invoices (doc. type, RE) not display offsetting-account or cost-object Asign?
entry.content:
Why do parked supplier invoices (document type RE) not expose offsetting-account or cost-object fields in any of the parked-document CDS views?

I am analysing the following parked-document CDS views:

‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocument ‚Äì parked document header (VBKPF)
‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocPyblsItem ‚Äì parked AP vendor items (VBSEGK)
‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocRblsItem ‚Äì parked AR customer items (VBSEGD)
‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocGLItem ‚Äì parked G/L items (VBSEGS)
‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocAssetItem ‚Äì parked asset items (VBSEGA)
‚Ä¢ I_ParkedOplAcctgDocItem ‚Äì generic parked-item cube

For G/L-type parked documents (SA), I_ParkedOplAcctgDocGLItem shows the offsetting-account and cost-object fields correctly.
However, for parked supplier invoices (RE), these fields appear empty when reviewing the document later (e.g. in the journal entry).

Is this because SAP does not store offsetting-account or cost-assignment data for RE-type parked invoices at VBSEGK/VBKPF level until the invoice is actually posted?
If so, is there any CDS view that can expose cost objects for parked RE invoices before posting?

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud session cookies remain after corporate IdP logout
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community!

currently we are facing an issue with our SAP Analytics Cloud, or rather the session management of the product. We created different stories in our SAC which we embedded in our corporate environment so our customers and employees can use them. This is done via iFrame. 

Our SAC has an Cloud Identity Instance as an IdP configured while the Cloud Identity Instance uses a Microsoft based corporate IdP where all SSO requests are forwarded. 

Now for the actual issue: After user A logs initiates a logoff in the corporate environment the session is terminated and the user is forwared to the login page again. But if user B does a login the SAC still has the session cookes from user A active and no further authentication flow is triggered. This means that user B works with the SAC user A until the browser is actually closed (since that is the cookie lifetime) 

We were under the impression that when the corporate IdP terminates the session, the Cloud Identity Service "tells" the Analytics Cloud to delete the session + cookies as well. 

Does anybody have a similar experience with SAC integrations via iFrame?

entry.title: Re: Unable to Get Sales Order number which are failed in...
entry.content:
Good day @Dinesh47 

Thank you for your question.

To summarise, the public cloud generally supports that information you seek through standard monitoring tools because there are no standard ALV-style reports that lists the sales orders which failed during the Schedule Delivery Creation job.

The system provides you the possibility to retrieve failed sales orders and their error message when you use Application Jobs. To achieve that:

First option is to use Job Applications. To do that open Application Jobs,

 ensure you filter the delivery creation job, then open the job log and display the application log.

This shows the sales order, item and the exact error message.

 

Second option is to monitor Sales Order fulfilment by opening Monitor Sales Order Fulfilment (If this Business role is assigned to you). Then used the Delivery Issues area to list all orders that failed delivery creation. The app will guide to root cause of the failure.

Alternatively, if you require a consolidated list, you may consider building a clean-core custom report through Custom CDS View and combined it with the fulfilment status APIs.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Does S/4 HANA not have the BUZID ?
entry.content:
Good day @Kimaro 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Blog: Handling of SELECT statements on simplified tables during S/4 HANA conversion

Universal Journal, Universal Journal: FAQ, Mapping Journal Entry Fields

To summarise, in all S4H editions the universal journal replaces tables such BSEG. Only some selected BSEG fields are brought into universal journal and BUZID is not one of them. Considering BUZID is also not exposed in public cloud through released CDS views, the filed cannot be reported, extended or added when you use custom fields.

If you need sub-identification for your accounting items, I recommend you use alternative fields such as Assignment Number, reference fields or Special G/L indicator.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Batch Management - Change Events - Clean Core Extensi...
entry.content:
I would expect both scenarios to be possible, although handling the events on-stack might be a bit easier. As long as the events are triggered from a RAP object, you can handle them locally without involving anything like Event Mesh on BTP. Events from objects for which there is no RAP object can only be handled using Event Mesh on BTP.

You can create a handler class in ADT to handle the event and code whatever is required. You should be able to update batch characteristics from there using EML. 

The tricky bits usually have to do with RAP phases, as I'm currently experiencing. You can't save anything in the MODIFY phase, you can't perform database updates in the SAVE phase... it all has to fit together exactly as SAP has intended or shortdumps will be your prize.

entry.title: Using Initiatives in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager ‚Äî Part 2 of a Series
entry.content:
After defining clear objectives, the next challenge is turning those objectives into coordinated, measurable action. This is where initiatives become the backbone of execution.

This article continues the series on SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, showing how the platform helps organizations move from strategy to delivery. The next part will focus on Insights and how they guide prioritization and continuous improvement.

How Initiatives Fit into SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager

For customers
In SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, an initiative represents a structured program of change aimed at fulfilling one or more business objectives. It is the container for everything that must happen to achieve a strategic goal ‚Äî from tasks and milestones to value targets.
The platform provides one central view of all initiatives, their relationships to objectives, and the progress they deliver across the business.

For partners
Initiatives offer a technical and functional integration point. Through the platform‚Äôs APIs, partners can:

  • create and update initiatives programmatically

  • synchronize initiatives with external project-management systems
  • connect performance dashboards or risk analytics
  • automate reporting and governance for transformation programs

This makes initiatives the anchor for partner-built accelerators and delivery frameworks.

What an Initiative Represents

An initiative is not a task list. It is a coordinated unit of work with:

  • a defined purpose
  • alignment to one or more objectives
  • ownership and accountability
  • a value hypothesis

In SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, initiatives are visual, comparable, and transparent ‚Äî enabling clear governance and consistent prioritization.

 

How to Use Initiatives Effectively

  1. Start from the objective, not the project list
    Initiative should link to at least one objective. If it does not support a strategic goal, it does not belong in the portfolio.

  2. Define scope and value early
    Capture the problem to be solved, the expected impact, and the value contribution. This helps prioritize initiatives rather than distribute effort blindly.

  3. Assign ownership
    Each initiative should have a single accountable owner. SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager makes this visible across all stakeholders.

  4. Plan milestones and dependencies
    Break the initiative into manageable steps and define critical dependencies. The platform helps map work, track status, and surface risks.

  5. Monitor and adjust
    Initiatives evolve. The platform enables status updates and course corrections as conditions change.

 Common Issues SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager Helps Avoid

  • Initiatives launched without strategy alignment
    The platform‚Äôs linkage to objectives prevents disconnected efforts.
  • Duplicate or overlapping initiatives
    A centralized portfolio reduces redundancy and reveals relationships.
  • Unclear ownership
    Visibility of roles and responsibilities eliminates ambiguity.
  • Too many parallel initiatives
    The portfolio view helps organizations decide what to pause, accelerate, or deprioritize.

 Why Initiatives Matter

Objectives define what has to change. Initiatives define how it will change.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager connects these two layers so organizations can steer transformation with clarity and evidence. Well-structured initiatives help teams focus, coordinate, and deliver measurable results rather than just activity.

entry.title: Re: Document type NB is not valid for Purchasing Group XX.‚Äù
entry.content:
Good day @mohamed_ezakraoui37 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Document Type of Purchase Requisition, Assign to My Purchasing Group, Manage Purchase Contracts

In summary, I will answer your last question first. There is no standard dependency between PR document type NB and Purchasing Group settings.

So, the error you mentioned is not caused by that. It is rather caused by the purchasing group not being assigned to the relevant purchasing team or a rule you create in substitution/validation rules may be enforcing a PG-DocType restriction. Also check your settings in UI/Field.

You can correct that issue by ensuring you assign PG ‚ÄúXX‚Äù to the operational purchasing responsibility. Then the rules for custom PR validation logic in Manage Substitution/Validation.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: My Real-World Guide to SAP Document & Reporting Compliance (DRC Series)
entry.content:
As someone who has worked extensively with SAP Document & Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC) across multiple countries and industries, I‚Äôve seen first-hand how rapidly tax regulations are evolving. Government authorities everywhere are shifting from post-factum tax reporting to real-time Continuous Transaction Controls (CTC).

And this shift is not subtle‚Äîit's massive.

Over the past few years, I‚Äôve helped organizations implement DRC for e-invoicing, SAF-T, e-transport documents, VAT/GST reporting, and more. We have even developed our own SAP DRC extensions and IP to tackle local nuances where standard functionality needed enhancements.

This blog is my attempt to bring together everything I‚Äôve learned so far‚Äîfrom basics to advanced concepts‚Äîin one place.

If you‚Äôre looking to truly understand SAP DRC‚Äîwhat it does, how it works, why it‚Äôs needed, and how it fits into SAP architecture‚Äîthis blog will guide you end-to-end.

  1. What is SAP DRC? (From My Experience)

From working on multiple implementations, I‚Äôve learned that SAP DRC is more than a tool‚Äîit's a framework.

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (SAP DRC) acts as the central backbone for:

  • Electronic invoicing
  • Real-time tax reporting (CTC)
  • Periodic statutory reporting
  • SAF-T and digital audit files
  • Digital signatures
  • Legal archiving
  • Automated interactions with government portals

The biggest value I‚Äôve seen in real projects is that DRC reduces manual tax compliance work by 80‚Äì90% and drastically cuts dependency on local middleware.

  1. Why Do Companies Need SAP DRC?

(What I‚Äôve Learned Implementing It Across Countries)

Almost every client I‚Äôve worked with is facing the same challenge:
Governments are moving toward real-time digital compliance.

Here‚Äôs the pattern I observed:

Region

Compliance Type

My Client Examples

Europe

SAF-T, e-Reporting, e-Invoicing

France, Poland, Portugal

LATAM

CTC, tax clearance before invoice validity

Mexico CFDI, Brazil NFe, Chile DTE

Middle East

Phase-wise e-Invoicing

KSA ZATCA, UAE

APAC

Govt-API‚Äìdriven e-invoicing

India IRN/QR

The risks companies face if they don‚Äôt comply are real:

‚ùåRejected invoices
‚ùåShipment block
‚ùåDelayed payments
‚ùåRegulatory penalties
‚ùåAudit red flags

In several implementations, I‚Äôve seen companies who initially relied on manual uploads or local middleware‚Äî
they inevitably had to switch to SAP DRC once volumes increased or rules tightened.

SAP DRC makes sure your SAP system speaks the legal language of your government portal.

  1. SAP DRC Architecture ‚Äî Explained From Practical Experience

When you work on DRC projects, this architecture becomes second nature.
Here‚Äôs the clearest way I explain it to clients:

 

In most projects, this means:

  • SAP S/4HANA generates the data
  • Document Compliance formats it
  • DRC Cloud and M2G manage API communication
  • Government returns status

I‚Äôve found this architecture extremely robust and scalable.

4. Key Components of SAP DRC (Based on Hands-On Work)

4.1 Document Processing (E-Invoicing)

This is where magic happens.

In our implementations, Document Compliance handled:

  • Structured XML/JSON generation
  • Mapping to country formats (ZATCA, IRN, CFDI, UBL, SDI, NFe)
  • Digital signatures
  • QR code generation
  • API submission
  • Government responses (success/error, UUID/IRN)
  • Legal archiving
  • Customer PDF + XML distribution

We've even built custom mapping logic and country add-ons as IP where clients needed country-specific non-standard fields.

4.2 Statutory Reporting

I‚Äôve used this extensively for:

  • VAT/GST returns
  • SAF-T files
  • E-transport documents
  • Withholding tax reports
  • Intrastat

ACR reports are extremely powerful for drill-down.

4.3 Machine-to-Government (M2G)

This is the most underrated part.

It ensures:

  • Secure API communication
  • Token & certificate lifecycle
  • Encryption
  • Response validation

We‚Äôve built reusable M2G wrappers as IP to simplify local government connections.

4.4 ACR (Advanced Compliance Reporting)

ACR allows:

  • Real-time dashboards
  • Pre-built country templates
  • Validations
  • Extensibility (BAdIs & custom logic)

We‚Äôve created custom ACR variants where the legal format or reporting rules weren‚Äôt standard.

5. How SAP DRC Works (Real End-to-End Flow I‚Äôve Implemented)

Step 1: Business Transaction

Customer invoice created in S/4HANA.

Step 2: Document Extraction

DRC picks the invoice automatically‚Äîno user involvement.

Step 3: Mapping & XML/JSON Generation

Step 4: Digital Signing & QR Code (where applicable)

Step 5: Submission to Government Portal

Step 6: Receive Govt Response

I‚Äôve seen everything here‚Äîsuccess, rejections, signature mismatches, schema errors.

Step 7: Archive & Distribution

Final legal XML + PDF sent to customer.

This flow is consistent across countries.

6. Regulations Supported by SAP DRC

(Exactly What I‚Äôve Implemented or Seen in Enterprise Projects)

6.1 E-Invoicing

  • India IRN
  • KSA ZATCA (Phase 1 & 2)
  • UAE FTA
  • Mexico CFDI
  • Brazil NFe
  • Chile DTE
  • Italy SDI
  • France PPF/PDP
  • Poland KSeF
  • Peppol regions: AU, SG, DK, NO

6.2 Real-Time Reporting

  • Hungary RTIR
  • Spain SII
  • Turkey e-Ar≈üiv

6.3 SAF-T

  • Poland
  • Portugal
  • Romania
  • Lithuania
  • Norway

6.4 Periodic Reporting

  • EU VAT
  • KSA VAT
  • UAE VAT
  • UK MTD
  • South Africa VAT201

6.5 Transport Reporting

  • India E-Way Bill
  • Hungary EKAER
  • Poland PEF

6.6 Our Intellectual Property Country Solutions

  • Albania SAP Community+2Crimson Partners+2
  • Croatia SAP Community+1
  • Romania SAP Community
  • Serbia SAP Community
  • Greece SAP Community
  • Mauritius SAP Community+1
  • Jordan Crimson Partners
  • Nigeria Crimson Partners
  • Israel Crimson Partners
  • Egypt Crimson Partners
  • Saudi Arabia Crimson Partners
  • United Arab Emirates Crimson Partners
  • Oman Crimson Partners
  • Pakistan Crimson Partners
  • Japan Crimson Partners
  • Vietnam Crimson Partners
  • Azerbaijan Crimson Partners
  • Kyrgyzstan Crimson Partners
  • Kazakhstan Crimson Partners
  • Uzbekistan Crimson Partners
  • Ghana Crimson Partners
  • Zambia Crimson Partners
  • Kenya Crimson Partners
  • Tanzania Crimson Partners
  • Congo Crimson Partners
  • Uganda Crimson Partners
  • Ivory Coast (C√¥te d‚ÄôIvoire) Crimson Partners
  • Morocco Crimson Partners

7. Automation Capabilities I‚Äôve Personally Delivered

‚úÖAutomated E-Invoicing

DRC delivers true end-to-end automation:

  • Auto-generate invoices
  • Auto-submit
  • Auto-validate
  • Auto-archive

‚úÖAutomated Statutory Reporting

Pre-populated data reduces manual work by almost 70%.

‚úÖAutomated Error Handling

We built custom reprocessing queues as part of our IP.

‚úÖWorkflow Driven Validations

Includes tolerance checks, approval flows, data consistency checks.

8. Security Features (Real-World Observations)

  • End-to-end encryption
  • Certificate signing
  • Audit trails
  • Tamper-proof logs
  • Legal archiving

These came in especially handy in KSA, Brazil, and EU implementations.

9. Business Benefits (What My Clients Experienced)

‚úî Zero manual uploads
‚úî Significantly reduced delays
‚úî One-click reports
‚úî Compliance with global mandates
‚úî Reliable scalable solution for future mandates
‚úî Less dependency on local providers
‚úî Standardized setup for all regions

10. SAP DRC vs Third-Party Tools (Based on My Experience)

Feature

SAP DRC

3rd Party

SAP Integration

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

11. Deployment Options I‚Äôve Worked On

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
  • SAP ECC (with BTP or PI/PO connectivity)

For ECC clients, we built integration IP for DRC‚Äìcloud connectivity.

12. SAP DRC Roadmap ‚Äì My Perspective

The future is definitely leaning toward:

  • EU ViDA digital reporting
  • Wider Peppol adoption
  • Cross-border e-invoicing
  • Multi-country CTC expansion

DRC is evolving fast‚ÄîSAP is preparing customers for the next 10 years of tax digitization.

This blog is posted by Khawaja Anas Hasan

entry.title: Re: Error in creating invoice based on PO (SMBEW Key Erro...
entry.content:
Below are the options to process converted POs with missing Valuation Type.

For POs with history but missing valuation type, you cannot retroactively fix them. Best practice is to block or close those PO items (set deletion indicator or final invoice flag). This prevents further processing and keeps history intact.

For any future procurement, create new POs referencing the correct valuation type. If the old PO still has open quantities, close them and re‚Äëorder with a new PO.

If invoices were already posted against POs without valuation type, you may need to handle valuation differences via manual FI postings or stock adjustments. This ensures your valuation reporting aligns with split valuation requirements.

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
This is a verrry long past-due switch from mnemonics to practicality, where both hard and soft skills may be tested.

It is though very important that the study material becomes more coherent, since too many times there is a clear mix of multiple contributing 'hands' that appear disjointed in terms of structure, language employed and expertise levels aggregated in the exam-bound documentation (i.e. highly analytical and transactional, or functional, for process/value-chain topics, while the focus should be on the logic, heuristic and business process emulation).

entry.title: Reporting of GHG emissions - Receiving actual emissions sent by your BN4L system
entry.content:
This blog provides additional information for those interested in Transportation Management and Sustainability. It serves as supplementary material to the blog "Reporting of GHG Emissions".

If you are operating a Business Network for Logistics system (BN4L) using GTT 2511, we have an exciting new business feature to enhance your Transportation Management within SAP S/4HANA . This feature enables you to receive GHG emissions data sent by your BN4L system.

For more details, refer to the "SAP Business Network Logistics 2511 Release" - innovations releasing in 2511 document and the "What's New Guide".

Your system landscape integrates Transportation Management embedded in SAP S/4HANA and Business Network for Logistics. In this setup, you may already be tracking your orders. With this new feature, you not only have the capability to receive actual emission data in your BN4L system from your carrier but also to forward this data to your Transportation Management system.

 

Fig. 1 illustrates the setup and data flow.

 

That's it for now.

Stay tuned, there is even more to come.

entry.title: Re: How to trigger SuccessFactors To-do or Email Notifica...
entry.content:
Hello,

As you may already know, there is no standardized configuration available for displaying To-Do Notifications on the SuccessFactors homepage or triggering email notifications directly within the system. Based on my experience, I have seen organizations develop backend reports to send email notifications to assigned users. The necessary information for these notifications is stored in the PYD_D_RESO table.

Regarding To-Do Notifications, I am not certain if it is feasible to achieve this functionality even through custom development, especially within ECP. However, you may want to explore the possibility of configuring notifications using a custom MDF object. Following SAP Knowledge Base Article provides detailed guidance on this process:

2560623 - Step by step configuration of MDF Alerts & Notifications [Custom MDF] - SAP for Me

A potential approach could be to populate a custom MDF object with the relevant data extracted from the PCC table, enabling the creation of notifications.

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: How to access failed messages from AEM Dead Message queue (DMQ) in Cloud Integration?
entry.content:
I have a scenario where i am connecting iFlow in CI to AEM via the AdvancedEventMesh adapter and as per the current design, i need to retry a failed message a few times (intermittent connectivity issue) before moving the message to a Dead message queue (DMQ) in AEM. My question here is 

  1.  How do i access the message from DMQ later and move it to the original queue for my iFlow to reprocess the message towards the target system?
  2. Should I create a separate queue for DMQ in the Broker manager?
  3. How do i make sure the retry process doesn't go on a loop if the message i retry from the DMQ doesn't get delivered to the target?

entry.title: Git, Grit, Giggle and no REST: My SAP Learning Curve (with Bumps!)
entry.content:
Hi all

It‚Äôs been a long time since my last blog‚Äîso long, in fact, that I can‚Äôt even remember it. As an ABAP developer with more years of experience than I care to admit, I find the new SAP environment for developers can be, well, overwhelming. You start learning one thing, only to discover you should have learned something else first, and then something before that‚Ä¶ and before you know it, you‚Äôre not sure where you started or where you‚Äôre supposed to end up.

At least, that‚Äôs how I felt‚Äîespecially because I‚Äôm learning on my own, without any external help, and my colleagues and I are taking the bumpy route.. We‚Äôve just finished converting the systems, and soon we‚Äôll have a flood of requests for apps and new features‚Äîwhile, of course, all the other projects keep rolling along like a runaway train.

So, I intend to create a series of posts to share my knowledge (whenever I have some time to write here) - because I got a lot of help from other people on the community but it was not easy to put it all together and that‚Äôs what I will try to do. I want to share what I‚Äôve learned, and also let you know: it‚Äôs not just you!

Here are my tips‚Äîhope they help (or at least make you laugh):

  1. Don‚Äôt get too hung up on the names. Just try stuff. Start small! I made a front-end app with no database access, and it helped me learn about MVC (Model-View-Controller scheme) and all those new buzzwords. In plain English: I used the Fiori Dev Space on Business Application Studio (the place you code apps), made a simple screen to compute data, and that was that. I had to learn about views and controllers just to do this basic thing.
  2. Make analogies to what you know. When you learn a new language, you try to find something similar in your native tongue to make sense of it. People say not to do that, but let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîyour brain craves comfort. ‚ÄúOh, this is like that? Great!‚Äù After a while, you‚Äôll get the nuances. For me, Views are like START-OF-SELECTION, Controllers are like AT SELECTION SCREEN and the logic is. Controller control the view. Is the comparison exactly the same? Nope. But it made me comfortable enough to move on.
  3. And GIT‚Ä¶ I was lucky to have used versioning tools when I start working with SAP, so it wasn‚Äôt totally new to me. Think of it like ABAP requests and tasks: you finish something, release it to test, and that‚Äôs a version. Then you release the full request. (Keep in mind, GIT is way more complex than that!) But that analogy helped me wrap my head around it.
  4. Adventures in BTP, GitLab, Git hub and permissions. Now, let me tell you about my adventure with BTP, GitLab, and all those things I had (and still have) no clue most of it. I spent‚Äîno joke‚Äîalmost three days trying to commit my app to GitLab, only to learn we actually use GitHub. Please, laugh at my pain. If my suffering brings joy to the world, it was worth it. Then I had to learn how to unlink GitLab, spent more days connecting to GitLab, only to discover I was missing permission to create a folder in my blank repository! I tried 100 commands, and only ONE finally told me it was a permission issue. Please, enjoy that suffering too. Eventually, I got the permission, typed the magic command, and‚Äîvoil√†!‚Äîit worked. I almost cried tears of joy. Always check your permissions! And remember, the start is hard‚ÄîI‚Äôm still at the start‚Äîbut learning this way, while painful, means you really learn. No one‚Äôs holding your hand, but you‚Äôll come out stronger (and with better stories).
  5. Make notes on everything you try, even if it doesn‚Äôt work. You never know when that random thing you checked will save your future self.
  6. Use AI, but don‚Äôt rely on it. Use AI, but don‚Äôt rely on it. I use Co-pilot and have access to Joule (thanks to a SAP POC), and AI can be a lifesaver‚Ä¶ but it also broke my simple app three times, forcing me to start over. At one point, AI was more lost than I was and started suggesting things that made me question reality. So, use AI, but keep your wits about you.
  7.  First things first‚ÄîGIT! And here‚Äôs the last tip: First things first‚ÄîGIT! If I‚Äôd focused on git (hub or lab, doesn‚Äôt matter), I could have saved the working version of my app, then gone wild with changes. If I messed up beyond repair (which, let‚Äôs be honest, happens), I could just roll back and start again from where it was working last.
  8. And the most important tip: Don‚Äôt give up. I thought about it, not gonna lie. But learning is awesome, and the feeling you get when you finally succeed is unbeatable.

What about you? How does it feel to move from ABAP to fullstack SAP development (or whatever they call it now, they change it so often).

Let's share tips and feelings. I know I'm not the only one.

Andr√©a
